title: Deleted File Gets Recreated When Browsing Chat History

labels.name: *duplicate
labels.description: Issue identified as a duplicate of another issue(s)

body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates -->
<!-- Please attach logs to help us diagnose your issue -->

**Product:** GitHub Chat (VS Code)
**Version:** `1.103.0-insider (Universal)`
**Commit:** `05ca6dd1bd6690aa2be81cc940ec308e5acc1c3d`
**Electron:** `37.2.3`
**Node.js:** `22.17.0`
**OS:** `Darwin arm64 25.0.0`

---

### 🧪 Steps to Reproduce:

1. In **GitHub Chat**, ask the GitHub Agent to generate a new file.
2. Manually delete that generated file from your workspace.
3. Start a **new conversation** in GitHub Chat.
4. Perform some actions unrelated to the deleted file in the new conversation.
5. Click on the **history** button and open the **previous conversation**.
6. **Observe:** the previously deleted file reappears in your workspace.

---

### ❌ Observed Behavior:

* When navigating back to a previous conversation via history, **deleted files are automatically recreated**.
* This also happens with edits — an older conversation can unexpectedly reapply changes that are no longer relevant.
* Creates a risk of **overwriting intentional deletions** and reintroducing outdated code.

---

### ✅ Expected Behavior:

* Navigating to a past conversation in chat history should **not automatically modify the workspace** unless explicitly confirmed by the user.
* Deleted files should **remain deleted** unless the user requests them to be recreated.
* Older edits should not be re-applied automatically when browsing history.

---

### 💡 Impact:

* Risk of **unintended code reintroduction** and merge conflicts.
* Confusing behavior when trying to maintain a clean working directory.
* Makes history navigation risky

title: Instructions: Allow filtering instructions to specific modes
body:
tl;dr: Add a `mode` field as filter to `.instructions.md`, so they can be matched to specific modes. This can help to refine copilot coding agent, code review, but also our any other modes that could be further refined with custom instructions (mode.

- Custom instructions are a mix of codebase guidance, _you are an expert programmer_, _this is where to file bugs_, _when and how to use tools_.
- Copilot coding agent instructions are heavy on project setup and CI/CD
- Code review instructions are more detailed on specific code best practices
- Fold in other cases that we had in settings: commit, tests, setup-tests

First cut `mode` makes this easy to control explicit, but filtering be later extended into labels or domains to allow some dynamic inclusion.

cc @timrogers

title: chat.mcp.serverSampling setting overwritten when using MCP: List Servers

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue identified by VS Code Team member as probable bug

labels.name: testing
labels.description: Built-in testing support

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->

- VS Code Version: 1.103.0
- VS Code Insiders Version: 1.104.0-insider
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Have multiple MCP entries in your mcp.json settings. Doesn't really matter what they are, you just need multiple to show up for the `MCP: List Servers`. For this example pretend I have two: `foo` and `bar`
2. Open up your settings.json file, find the section 
3. In your command bar, use `MCP: List Servers -> foo -> Configure Model Access`. Pick a few.
4. Look in your settings.json, you should see something like:
```
    "chat.mcp.serverSampling": {
        "Global in Code - Insiders: foo": {
            "allowedModels": [
                "copilot/gpt-4.1",
                "copilot/auto",
                "copilot/claude-3.5-sonnet",
                "copilot/claude-3.7-sonnet",
                "copilot/claude-3.7-sonnet-thought",
                "copilot/claude-sonnet-4",
                "copilot/gemini-2.0-flash-001",
                "copilot/gemini-2.5-pro",
                "copilot/gpt-4o",
                "copilot/gpt-5",
                "copilot/o3-mini",
                "copilot/o4-mini"
            ]
        }
    }
```
5. In your command bar, use `MCP: List Servers -> bar -> Configure Model Access`. Pick a few.
6. Look in your settings.json, you should see something like:
```
    "chat.mcp.serverSampling": {
        "Global in Code - Insiders: bar": {
            "allowedModels": [
                "copilot/gpt-4.1",
                "copilot/auto",
                "copilot/claude-3.5-sonnet",
                "copilot/claude-3.7-sonnet",
                "copilot/claude-3.7-sonnet-thought",
                "copilot/claude-sonnet-4",
                "copilot/gemini-2.0-flash-001",
                "copilot/gemini-2.5-pro",
                "copilot/gpt-4o",
                "copilot/gpt-5",
                "copilot/o3-mini",
                "copilot/o4-mini"
            ]
        }
    }
```
Notice how your previous settings for `foo` have been removed. If you bring up the `Configure Model Access` for `foo` again, you'll see that the checklist is reset to what it was originally.

title: Title: "‘Open with Code’ context menu option missing in VS Code version 103.0"

labels.name: *duplicate
labels.description: Issue identified as a duplicate of another issue(s)

body:
Description:
I have updated Visual Studio Code to version 103.0, and after the update, the ‘Open with Code’ option in the Windows Explorer context menu has disappeared. This was working perfectly fine in previous versions. The absence of this option makes it inconvenient to open folders/files directly from Explorer in VS Code.
Steps to Reproduce:
Update VS Code to version 103.0 (latest). 
Right-click on any folder or file in Windows Explorer. 
Observe that the ‘Open with Code’ option is missing from the context menu. 
Expected Behavior:
The ‘Open with Code’ option should be visible in the Windows Explorer context menu, allowing quick access to open files/folders in VS Code.
Actual Behavior:
The ‘Open with Code’ option is missing from the context menu after updating to version 103.0.
Additional Information:
I tried reinstalling VS Code and ensuring the context menu options are selected during installation, but the issue persists. 
Downgrading to an earlier stable version restores the option correctly. 
Automatic updates are disabled to avoid the bug. 

Environment:
VS Code version: 103.0

title: Copilot takes a long time initializing "vue-typescript-plugin-pack"

labels.name: *caused-by-extension
labels.description: Issue identified to be caused by an extension

body: I am not sure if this is the proper place or label for this issue. It is not related to the agent itself, but to the vue-typescript-plugin-pack loaded for copilot. When copilot is enabled in a vue project with typescript support, initializing the vue-typescript-plugin-pack takes longer than a full minute, which breaks intellisense, code actions, or any interoperability with the tsserver. I created this repository with a fairly minimal reproduction scenario: https://github.com/stweedie/slow-copilot There are full logs in the "logs" folder, but I included some relevant bits in the logs section of this issue below. The issue does not exist if I have copilot disabled in extensions. - Copilot Chat Extension Version: 0.30.0 -VSCode about: Version: 1.103.0 Commit: e3550cfac4b63ca4eafca7b601f0d2885817fd1f Date: 2025-08-06T21:40:10.271Z Electron: 37.2.3 ElectronBuildId: 12035395 Chromium: 138.0.7204.100 Node.js: 22.17.0 V8: 13.8.500258-electron.0 OS: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100 Also, my repositories are using the remote extension for WSL2 - Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode): agent and ask - Selected model (e.g. GPT 4.1, Claude 3.7 Sonnet): Any - Logs: with copilot disabled: https://github.com/stweedie/slow-copilot/blob/61e34a9abb094fd45afc007ecb598914709b3ffe/logs/copilot-disabled.log#L148-L153 with copilot enabled: https://github.com/stweedie/slow-copilot/blob/61e34a9abb094fd45afc007ecb598914709b3ffe/logs/copilot-enabled.log#L868-L874 Steps to Reproduce: 1. Clone repo https://github.com/stweedie/slow-copilot 2. Open workspace in vscode 3. Use copilot chat to generate a new vue component (or modify an existing vue component) 4. Open any .vue file (like src/components/HelloWorld.vue) 5. tsserver seems to take a long time (over a minute in most cases) initializing the "vue-typescript-plugin-pack" from github.copilot-chat. Until that time, intellisense is broken, and if you have code actions on save, those will also be blocked until the plugin initializes. This plugin gets "initialized" for every .vue file you open:

title: Implement conditional file watching for terminal commands with chat editing service integration
body:
This PR implements a system for intelligently detecting file operations in terminal commands and integrating with VS Code's chat editing service to track file changes, without disrupting the normal terminal execution flow.

## Problem

Previously, there was no mechanism to track when terminal commands performed file operations that could be relevant to ongoing chat editing sessions. Commands like `cat file.txt`, `mkdir new-dir`, or file modifications would execute without any integration with VS Code's editing workflow.

## Solution

This implementation provides a non-intrusive monitoring system that:

### File Operation Detection
- **Command Pattern Recognition**: Detects file operations using `FileOperationHeuristics` class with regex patterns for `cat`, `type`, `mkdir`, `ls`, and other commands
- **File Path Extraction**: Handles quoted paths, multiple files, and various command formats
- **No Command Interruption**: Commands execute normally in the terminal without any re-routing

### Chat Editing Service Integration
- **Post-execution Analysis**: After command completion, analyzes output using regex heuristics to detect actual file changes
- **Chat Service Reporting**: Reports detected file changes to `IChatEditingService` for integration with ongoing editing sessions
- **URI Resolution**: Properly converts relative and absolute file paths to URIs for VS Code integration

## Key Features

**Enhanced File Change Detection:**
```typescript
// Detects file reading operations
const heuristics = new FileOperationHeuristics();
heuristics.detectCommandType('cat README.md')  // Returns: 'file-read'
heuristics.extractFilePaths('cat "file with spaces.txt" config.json')  // Returns: ['file with spaces.txt', 'config.json']
```

**Post-execution File Change Analysis:**
```typescript
// Analyzes command output for actual file changes
analyzeCommandExecutionForFileChanges('mkdir new-project', 'created directory new-project')
// Returns: { detectedFileChanges: ['new-project'], confidence: 'high' }
```

## Implementation Details

- **FileOperationHeuristics**: Core class for detecting file operations and extracting file paths
- **IChatEditingService Integration**: Reports file changes to chat editing sessions
- **Conditional Monitoring**: Only activates file watching for commands that involve file operations
- **Seamless Terminal Experience**: Maintains normal terminal workflow without interruptions

## Supported Commands

- **File Reading**: `cat file.txt`, `type config.json` (Windows)
- **Directory Creation**: `mkdir new-dir`, `mkdir -p deep/nested/path`
- **Future Extensibility**: Framework ready for `ls`, `echo >`, and other file operations

The system runs terminal commands normally while tracking file changes using regex heuristics and reporting them to the chat editing service for better integration with VS Code's editing workflow.

Fixes #253884.

title: [FREQ]  When AI proposing block of code, include comment or pop-up explaining intent

labels.name: stale
labels.description: Issues that have not been triaged in an appropriate amount of time

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

Too often, I find the insertion of blocks of "proposed code" actually cost me more effort, not less, because it requires fairly close examination and code review in many cases to ensure that the AI actually _understood_ the context of the surrounding code, and that its suggested code actually solves the need I was trying to implement.  Too often it will make proposals from surrounding API use, but totally whiff on what I was trying to do, and it isn't always immediately obvious that's the case unless you closely study how it implemented the code.

If we could get a comment at the top of the block (or perhaps in a pop-up window) where the AI explains what the added code actually does / is trying to address, it would allow users to reject inappropriate suggestions much faster than forcing a intense code inspection just to discern whether what it provided is really what you were intending to implement.

Just to be crystal-clear:  What's needed is just detail on what the code the AI suggested does/addresses.  I understand the way it resolves "context cues" doesn't necessarily equate to it being able to provide detailed low-level understanding of the code's purpose, but even in those cases, knowing what attributes/tags made it select that code for suggestion is still better than nothing at all in terms of quickly assessing whether appropriate.

title: Aligning synced vscode sources between vscode/vscode-copilot-chat

labels.name: debt
labels.description: Code quality issues

body:
I had issues syncing vscode sources into the chat extension (see https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-copilot-chat/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md#use-basecommon-utils) due to some differences in the core/edits files.

The PR is at https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-copilot-chat/pull/518. I made some manual edits here

- https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-copilot-chat/pull/518/commits/4b82e6bb4649715de8cae316d0edb6eaf8b4accc to avoid some type errors that I couldn't figure out how to resolve
- https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-copilot-chat/pull/518/commits/2108e213b9019dcb9616ae16e93763e31d30f478 to hook up this `ensureDependenciesAreSet` function

Then after that, I still have some vitest failures, I think because there used to be a `JSON.stringify` here https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-copilot-chat/blob/2108e213b9019dcb9616ae16e93763e31d30f478/src/util/vs/editor/common/core/edits/stringEdit.ts#L204.

Could you look at these? I'm also not sure what other manual changes might have been made that might be missing but not causing build or test failures. I'd really like to get back to a place where we can do a clean run of `copySources.ts` to keep things in sync. 

(I also am working through this issue https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/260650, there are currently more manual edits in the PR branch for that)

title: Sync vscode sources in vscode-copilot-chat

labels.name: debt
labels.description: Code quality issues

body:
Had issues syncing vscode sources into the chat extension (see https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-copilot-chat/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md#use-basecommon-utils) due to a difference in base .d.ts between the two.

PR https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-copilot-chat/pull/518

The typecheck script failed with errors like this `Error: src/util/vs/base/common/async.ts(520,3): error TS2741: Property '_' is missing in type 'Timeout' but required in type 'TimeoutHandle'.`

https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-copilot-chat/actions/runs/16837700919/job/47701113942#step:10:15


If I just run the `npx tsc --noEmit --project test/simulation/workbench/tsconfig.json` part, it fails, but if I run `npx tsc --noEmit --project tsconfig.json` it doesn't fail. I made this commit https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-copilot-chat/pull/518/commits/45f35b0c368665a4ae0e93cbd7413b7de793591d to work around it. I can't figure out why this is happening but it seems like the simulation workbench build just doesn't see the `base-common.d.ts` overload of `setTimeout`. When that error says `Timeout` it's referring to `NodeJS.Timeout`, not the `Timeout` type in that file. Any ideas @bpasero?  

If you want to try it yourself, you can check out that PR, just make sure you either get the commit before https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-copilot-chat/pull/518/commits/45f35b0c368665a4ae0e93cbd7413b7de793591d or revert that change. Then run `npm run typecheck`.

title: Add terminal/shell mode to chat input

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: chat-terminal
labels.description: The run in terminal tool in chat

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

Frequently I would like to run a command in the terminal that i know would very likely to fail and have GitHub Copilot give me insights on what to do with the errors. As of today, I can achieve this using two approaches:

- Run the command myself and then prompt to the GitHub Copilot to look at the last command output.
- Prompt to let GitHub Copilot run the command for me, which very likely will trigger a "run command" confirmation that I need to click one more time to approve.

I would like to have a shortcut in the window that that can allow me to achieve this easier. For example, I may be able to run a slash command and give it the command:

`/terminal echo 'hello world'`

In some way it's similar to how you can run a bash command in Vim using `:!`.

title: VSCode Copilot Chat update 0.30 Says it performs FileOps but doesn't. Reverting to 0.29 has stopped it working completely.
body:
- Copilot Chat Extension Version: 0.30, 0.29
- VS Code Version:1.103.0
- OS Version:Windows 10
- Selected model : Claude Sonnet 4.0 selected - although the model told me it was 3.5

Copilot tried to perform a number of file ops.
- Copilot reported each file op as done
- Unlike in 0.29, Copilot did not prompt me to approve these FileOps
- When I checked the file system, none of the ops were done
- Zero length files that I had deleted before this session had been restored
- It did not appear that Copilot could send commands to the terminal - as it had done 
before. It asked me to copy and paste these commands for it.
- I asked Copilot to verify FileOps had happened - it did this during the turn - but when
I pointed out that nothing had happened - it agreed!

Also, a couple of requests appeared in the chat that neither Copilot or 
myself could take credit for. These were:-
'Rollback GitHub Copilot Chat extension to version 0.29 due to issues with file operations in version 0.30.'
and
'"#new workspace setup"
The latter caused further confusion as, although the conversation seemed to be copied to the workspace, Copilot could no longer see the files in the workspace. It asked me to change back to the original workspace, but, as expected, when I did, the end of the conversation was missing.  

It then asked me to check a few things. I checked the VSCode Chat extension had 
very recently been updated - and it looked like a big update. I copied the change log into the chat 
and let Copilot analyse it. It came back with :-

' The terminal integration was completely rewritten and moved from the extension to VS Code core. The new system is much more restrictive about file operations and requires proper "shell integration" to work correctly.'

(Does this mean VSCode is also compromised after this update ?)

Anyway, Copilot suggested this setting:-

"chat.tools.terminal.autoApprove": {
  // Allow common file operations
  "/^(Move-Item|Remove-Item|New-Item)\\b/i": true
}
- or to rollback.

I decided to rollback to 0.29. First I just selected 0.29 and restarted. Then I uninstalled/reinstalled 
VSCode Copilot chat 0.29. In both cases the chat is no longer working. There is no longer a 
list of agents to select from. When you send a request, you just get a neverending 'working...' prompt.

Github Copilot(Claude Sonnet 4.0(3.5?)) has been absolutely brilliant up to this update. It was so weirdly bad it 
felt like I'd slipped into an alternate universe ! I've spent about 5 hours investigating debugging testing and reporting this bug in somebody elses software - and I see about a million other people have also reported problems in the last few hours - so they've also had there own special time with version 0.30 - and just to rub salt in it, my premium request usage has gone up 5% !

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

Sometimes I need to drag a file from the IDE and drop in some Websites, is the most time to IA web agents. 
In another IDEs like Intellij the files can be dropped from the file explorer or file tree direct to the Website.

The idea is to allow dropping the items from explorer like real files, causing the uploads on the website on another Window.

title: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'length')

labels.name: *out-of-scope
labels.description: Posted issue is not in scope of VS Code

body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates -->
<!-- Please attach logs to help us diagnose your issue -->

- Copilot Chat Extension Version: 1.350.0
- VS Code Version: 1.103.0
- OS Version: Windows 11
- Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode): Agent
- Selected model (e.g. GPT 4.1, Claude 3.7 Sonnet): GPT 4.1

Steps to Reproduce:

I am building an extension that exposes some MCP tools, and I seem to have run into this error when building my tool.

> Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'length') (at tsx element FA > IF > cse > SSe > Mo > <anonymous> > <anonymous> > h6 > ESe > CSe > Of)

When the servers response back is with something like this, where text is `undefined`, the error shows. However, if I do null coalesce, such as `text: text ?? ''`, the error goes away.

```ts
import { McpServer } from '@modelcontextprotocol/sdk/server/mcp.js';

/* Create server here */


/* ran within a tool */
server.tool('test, 'test descr', async () => {
  const text = callFunction(); // unexpectedly returns undefined

  // MCP response outputs to sdio: JSON.stringify(result)
  const result = {
      content: [
        {
          type: 'text',
          text: text, // using null coalesce fixes it, but it should be handled by the editor I would think
        },
      ],
  }

  return JSON.stringify(result);
});
```

title: NES has good suggestion then switches to odd suggestion
body:
1. have a long line with an anonymous object

```
this._notifyAction({ kind: 'chatEditingHunkAction', uri: this.modifiedURI, outcome: action.state, lineCount: action.lineCount, hasRemainingEdits: action.hasRemainingEdits });
```

2. use new lines to start putting each property on its own line

:bug: NES will offer to continue the task correctly, but before I can react, it changes to deleting the rest of the object

title: "Open with VS Code" Option Missing After Latest Update

labels.name: *duplicate
labels.description: Issue identified as a duplicate of another issue(s)

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
Description:
After updating Visual Studio Code to the latest version, the "Open with VS Code" option is no longer available in the right-click context menu. This feature was previously available and I used it frequently to open projects directly from File Explorer.

Steps to Reproduce:

Install the latest version of Visual Studio Code.

Right-click any folder in File Explorer.

Look for the "Open with VS Code" option in the context menu.

Expected Behavior:
The right-click context menu should display the "Open with VS Code" option.

Actual Behavior:
The "Open with VS Code" option is missing from the context menu.

Impact:
This affects my workflow as I often open projects directly from the context menu instead of manually navigating inside VS Code.

Request:
Please restore this feature or provide instructions to re-enable it.

title: Skip Tool for Agent Mode
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
We'd like to see if instead of just "Cancel" or "Continue" option for invoking a tool - whether a "Skip" option for invoking a tool tool could be implemented, in the event that a tool is not necessary, but you'd like the agent to keep going regardless.

title: Terminal Issue: terminal.integrated.automationProfile.windows does not respect "env" object
body:

title: Since 1.103.0, Copilot chat run_in_terminal lose context after first tool call in the same terminal
body: - Copilot Chat Extension Version: - VS Code Version: Version: 1.103.0 (Universal) Commit: e3550cfac4b63ca4eafca7b601f0d2885817fd1f - OS Version: Darwin arm64 24.5.0 (Mac OS 15.5) - Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode): agent - Selected model (e.g. GPT 4.1, Claude 3.7 Sonnet): Claude 4 Sonnet - Logs: attached below It seems like since 1.103.0, `run_in_terminal` isn't capturing the output of the terminal properly when running subsequent commands in the same terminal. The first command output is captured as expected. It looks like it has something to do with the ZSH theme decoration that shows the branch name on the terminal prompt, as it didn't seem to happen in a folder without git, but it could also be caused by something else. Steps to Reproduce: 1. ask `run a terminal command to generate a random number and give me the output`. The first run captures the output fine. 2. ask `run it again`. The output isn't properly captured and Copilot chat thinks that the command didn't run. Copilot chat debug: [run_a_terminal_command_to_generate_a_random_number_exports.tar.gz](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/21685611/run_a_terminal_command_to_generate_a_random_number_exports.tar.gz) [run_it_again_exports.tar.gz](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/21685612/run_it_again_exports.tar.gz)

title: Suggest widget: Bug fix - when widget is too tall, ensure larger of above and below space is used.
body: **Issue addressed:** https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/152324 **Description:** Currently, when the suggest widget has enough space below, everything is fine: When the suggest widget is larger than the area below the current line, the current code always calculates the height and position of the widget using the space **above** the line (even if the space below is larger): With this change, if the suggest box is larger than the space below, it will now choose the largest of "above" and "below" to use in its calculations (unless force-above is enabled):
